title: How to Apply Foundation with a Sponge

steps.title: Cleanse your face first.
steps.content: Cleanse your face first. If you want your foundation to look smooth and even, it's important to maintain a good skincare routine. [1] X Expert Source Ashleigh Grounds Makeup Artist & Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 22 April 2020. Use cleanser and warm water to wash your face . Water that’s too hot or cold might irritate your skin. Massage the cleanser gently into your skin with your fingertips. After you've washed your face thoroughly, rinse away the cleanser with warm water, making sure you don't leave any residue. When you're finished, gently pat your face dry with a towel. You may also want to mist your face with toner to help rebalance your skin.

steps.title: Moisturize your face.
steps.content: Moisturize your face. Using moisturizer immediately after you wash your face will help your skin hold in moisture. Plus, your foundation will blend more evenly and create a flawless look when your skin is well-moisturized. Let the moisturizer dry for at least 1 minute. If you can’t wait for the moisturizer to dry, blot your face with a tissue after moisturizing.

steps.title: Apply foundation primer.
steps.content: Apply foundation primer. Squirt a pea-sized amount of primer onto the back of your hand. Blend the primer into your face using gentle circular motions with your fingertips. Let it dry for 2 to 3 minutes before adding foundation. [2] X Research source Different kinds of primers have different uses, so choose one that matches your skincare needs. For instance, if you have an uneven skin tone, you might pick a primer that balances out redness or covers dark spots. If you have fine lines or large pores, you might choose a primer that helps fill those areas in. [3] X Expert Source Ashleigh Grounds Makeup Artist & Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 22 April 2020.

steps.title: Use a slightly damp makeup sponge for natural-looking coverage.
steps.content: Use a slightly damp makeup sponge for natural-looking coverage. Wet your makeup sponge and squeeze out excess water until it's just damp. A slightly damp sponge won’t soak up excess foundation. You'll be able to build foundation gradually onto your face for a natural look. An egg-shaped Beautyblender is one of the most popular types of makeup sponges, but you can also try a wedge or flocked sponge. Don't wring out the sponge or squeeze it tightly. By doing so, you may be damaging the sponge. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Pour a dime-sized amount of foundation onto the back of your hand.
steps.content: Pour a dime-sized amount of foundation onto the back of your hand. Doing this rather than pouring directly from bottle to sponge will ensure you don’t waste excess foundation. Only pour a small amount at first. You can always pour more onto your hand if needed. [5] X Research source If you are using pressed powder foundation, you can dip the sponge directly into the foundation. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Dip your sponge gently into the foundation on your hand.
steps.content: Dip your sponge gently into the foundation on your hand. Dip the thickest, widest part of the sponge into the foundation on your hand. Since your sponge is still damp, the foundation won’t soak into the sponge. Start with only a little foundation at first, so you can get used to blending with the sponge.

steps.title: Dab foundation onto the center of your face and blend outward.
steps.content: Dab foundation onto the center of your face and blend outward. Start from the center of your face and move towards your hairline. Use a gentle bouncing or tapping motion to distribute the foundation onto your skin. Dabbing rather than rubbing will apply makeup more evenly and naturally. [7] X Research source Makeup artists call this “stippling.” [8] X Research source

steps.title: Continue dabbing foundation into your face and neck until blended.
steps.content: Continue dabbing foundation into your face and neck until blended. If your sponge is egg-shaped, use the small pointed edge around your eyes and nose. Use the larger, round part of your sponge for your cheeks, forehead and jawline. Blend until the foundation looks like your natural skin. [9] X Research source If you can see where the blended foundation meets your neck, the color may be too dark or too light. Make sure you’ve chosen the best foundation for your skin type and tone. Only apply the foundation to your jawline and neck when there is a small amount of foundation left on the sponge.

steps.title: Wait 2 to 3 minutes or finish applying your makeup, then apply setting powder.
steps.content: Wait 2 to 3 minutes or finish applying your makeup, then apply setting powder. Let the foundation set for a few minutes and finish applying any other makeup you want to wear before applying setting powder, which will keep the foundation in place. You can use your makeup sponge or a small fluffy makeup brush to apply the powder in a gentle dabbing motion. [10] X Research source Setting powder can also help set your eyeliner, mascara, or lipstick.

steps.title: Wash your sponge with facial cleanser or mild soap after every use.
steps.content: Wash your sponge with facial cleanser or mild soap after every use. You can also use makeup cleanser for sponges. Rinse your sponge in warm water and massage it with a few drops of facial cleanser or mild soap. If the sponge is stained with makeup, then you can also soak it in soapy water overnight. Rinse and wring it out until the water from the sponge runs clear. Bacteria and mold can grow quickly in sponges, and using a dirty sponge can make blending foundation harder. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Let your sponge air dry before using it again.
steps.content: Let your sponge air dry before using it again. After washing your sponge, roll it back and forth onto a clean towel to remove remaining moisture. Let it dry flat on the towel completely. You should replace old sponges every 3 months. [12] X Research source
